Reviews.Content: Great hotel in a good location Well located hotel 15 minutes from the main train station. They have a complimentary Shuttle from the hotel to the train station and shops, every 20 minutes all day long.A great spa and warm swimming pool, and overall a very pleasant experience. Rooms were good size, and comfortable with free internet excess in the rooms, and very clean. The airport bus drops off at the front door, and picks up at the same spot. I would stay at this location again.
Reviews.Author: enr12

Reviews.Content: Plain, clean, somewhat dated Shinjuku by itself is not a very exciting place (as Tokyo goes) but it's proximity to the main train exchange and Times Square make it a spirited walk away from the fun. Travelers on their initial visits to Japan will benefit from many signs being written in both Japanese and Englieh, not the case in many other areas of Japan. Shomben Yokocho (a small warren of old classic Japanese cookery and shopping) is near Shinjuku station as is Shinjuku Eastmouth high street shopping area and Kabukicho Red Light district. (For those of you well traveled, Kabukicho is not like an informative walk through the Amsterdam red-light district- it is seedy and overrun with agressive barkers and Central European and Asian street sex workers.) The hotel itself is clean, but could use a refresh. The rooms are nice, small as expected and seem locked in a mid-80s decor. There is a decent selection of restaruants (sushi bar is top notch and top dollar) and a liquor bar but don't confuse the liquor bar with anything exciting- it's a dim, leather padded haunt for business types and their wives/significant others. Take the walk or a taxi down to Times Square and find yourself a barstool or decent restaurant and watch japan go by, much more fun! The beds are comfortable (make sure to reserve non-smoking in advance if you want it, there are still a lot of smoking rooms in Japan) and the bathrooms are bright with lots of amenities and the usual deep Japanese bathtub.Departing from the airport the bus ride can be a walk outside to the bus and get on immediately 1.5 hour affair or, as in maddeningly typical, you just missed the last bus, wait 45 mins for another and then 2 hrs in traffic. The bus does take you door to door though. There is the train which is a predictable 90+ mins but you must change trains in Tokyo. If you have a lot of luggage go with the bus- trains can be very crowded after you get off the Narita-Tokyo express. Don't even think about a taxi- US 250-300.00 are the norm for this trip. Note: PLAN AHEAD for your trip back to Narita- reserve your train or bus ticket early and contemplate the possibility of 2hrs to get to Narita.
Reviews.Author: kvf1

Reviews.Content: Great Hotel This hotel exceeded my expectations. The staff was very friendly, helpful and always greeted us promptly and professionally. The front desk staff and concierge spoke excellent English and were able to assist us with directions and translation. We utilized the travel agency in the lobby to make our Shinkensen reservations. Our room was clean, comfortable and spacious. We splurged and booked a king room with a city view. It was well worth it because we had a beautiful view facing west which overlooks a park and the sunset in the evening. We took the limousine bus from Narita Airport directly to and from the hotel. The hotel provides a free shuttle to and from Shinjuku Station which saved a lot of time.
Reviews.Author: Skrat

Reviews.Content: Great staff and pleasant hotel Stayed at the Hyatt Regency for 3 nights, our 2nd stay in 2 years. Like last time, we used points to upgrade to a club room, and really the Regency Club is the highlight of the hotel. The club is open to those staying in the Club rooms and consists of 3 or 4 interlinked lounges, all tastefuly decorated. They serve a generous breakfast, mostly continental style but also including some hot dishes, smoked salmon etc, and cocktails every evening between 6 and 8, with a really good range of drinks. It became a really pleasant start to the evening to sit in the lounge with a couple of drinks, overlooking the lights of Shinjuku, especially considering the prices in the hotel bar! Also worth knowing is that Hyatt Gold passport members get entry to the healthclub and pool free, otherwise like most Japanese hotels there is a hefty charge, around 2500 Yen!This a very pleasant hotel and the staff particularly are excellent, consistently polite, helpful and friendly. My only slight niggles are in the rooms themselves- even the club room we had is starting to look a little bit dated, as the room could be a little dark and the bathroom is nothing special. Our 2nd hotel in Tokyo was the Prince Park Tower, and the bathroom there was very very good!Overall, a nice hotel in a convenient location, but try to get a club room, as it makes the stay special!
Reviews.Author: KMcH

Reviews.Content: Comfortable Business hotel I stayed at the Hyatt regency for two weeks in August for Business. I had a good stay there, the room was a good size, the food was good and the staff couldn't do enough for you. The hotel is situated in the business area of Shinjuku sandwiched between the government Building and several other tall buildings, and a small park. There is a complementary shuttle bus to Shinjuku station that operates every 20 minutes or you can walk there in about 10 minutes. In August I'd recommend the air-conditioned bus as it is so hot and sticky.Before my trip I registered with the Hyatt gold passport loyalty reward scheme, having done this and despite not having stayed in a Hyatt before I was put into a Hyatt gold passport room on check in. This membership also entitled me to free use of the pool and gym. The room I was in was very spacious for a Japanese hotel, I had a Super king size bed a couple of lounging chairs a small table and a desk to work at. There is also free Internet in the rooms. The bathroom was well equipped and had a shower adequate for my height, which I have struggled with in the past in East Asian hotels.The hotel is quite large and as such has several restaurants and a bar. The staff at the restaurants were always extremely welcoming and friendly. The breakfast buffet was of a high quality with a varied and plentiful choice of food.The main restaurant has great service; you could be in and out in 30minutes, which is great if you are eating on your own. I didn't feel rushed though. Hidden away under the building adjoined to the hotel is AM/PM convenience shop. This sells hot/cold snacks and beer if you don't fancy eating restaurant food again. There are many of other places to eat around the Hotel and in Shinjuku itself if you want to venture out into the sticky heat.
Reviews.Author: Lancs_Lizzy

Reviews.Content: Good Location - Average Hotel Tokyo was overwhelming before I even got there as I tried to figure out all the different neighborhoods. I do suggest Shinjuku where this Hyatt is located. Its a quick walk, or free shuttle ride, to the main Station. From there you can shop, eat and/or jump on a train to explore the rest of the city.As for the Hotel-well, its in need of a facelift. There wasn't anything wrong with the rooms - I enjoyed the space and views to the East. But the lobby is an un-spectacular atrium with fake ivy. The Regency Club Breakfast room should be an embarassment to Hyatt - a small room with furniture from the 1980s. Not what you'd expect out of a Hyatt in a major, metropolitan, cutting edge city like Tokyo.
Reviews.Author: TheCaliTraveler

Reviews.Content: Better than average business hotel I stayed here while on business for 7 days. It was my first trip to Japan, so I was glad to stay in an American chain for a bit of familiarity. The hotel is very large and suprisingly the room was quite large as well. I have had much smaller rooms in NY or Europe. The hotel staff was very hospitable and friendly, even when asking my coworker and I to move to an office just off the main lobby so that we could continue eating the little cakes we just got at the bakery. Note - although you can buy little cakes in the bakery off the lobby, they don't intend for you to eat them there.Overall, it was a pleasant experience - not visually stunning or luxurious by any means, but definitely comfortable.
Reviews.Author: audreyliz

Reviews.Content: Large hotel       another angle (sorry I had to erase my daughter)
Reviews.Author: cricketa

Reviews.Content: Good, but not great. We recently visited the Hyatt Regency in Tokyo for 3 nights and i must say i wasnt overly impressed. We had just come from the Hyatt Regency in Kyoto and it was not in the same class (see Kyoto review- thoroughly enjoyed it!). Nonetheless, the staff were reasonably friendly, the location quiet and fairly convenient. The bathroom was a bit small and the decor in the room needs an update. Overall, there was nothing particularly wrong with this hotel, but nothing 'stand out' either.
Reviews.Author: SydneySider07

Reviews.Content: Spa Lovers in Tokyo       Friendly staff of the Hyatt
Reviews.Author: EChavezNY

Reviews.Content: Impeccable service never fail       Bedroom
Reviews.Author: yrtx4e

Reviews.Content: Loved it lots! I have stayed at this hotel several times both with my husband on his business trips and on our own holidays. I have never had any complaints to lodge as everything is just so wonderful about the Hyatt brand. It's so conveniently located, a 10 minutes walk to the Shinjuku station and if you are taking the Toei line, it's located just below the hotel. My room didn't come with free breakfast but there are a number of good cafes nearby for a quick and simple breakfast. As it's in the Shinjuku district, there are also a number of good restaurants nearby for meals. The concierge is exceptionaly helpful.
Reviews.Author: sweet_mermaid

Reviews.Content: Great Location! Great Hotel! One of the best and most convenient perks of this hotel was their shuttle service from Shinjuku Station which is one of if not the busiest station in Tokyo. You can pretty much get anywhere from this station. We did find it a little bit difficult to find the bus stop of the shuttle so here's a few tips; From Shinjuku station, make your way to Okakyu Department store which is on the West Exit. Once you exit, you'll see another department store called Keio across the road. You'll find the bus stop infront of the street level entrance. The shuttle to the hotel leaves Shinjuku station every 20mins (10, 30, 50 every hour up from 8:10am - 9:50pm). Make sure you're on time!! Like most other people we were WOW'd by the chandeliers in the lobby!! They really are amazing!! Thanks heaps to the other reviewers that suggested signing up to the hotel membership. We were able to have breakfast every morning! :)As for the hotel itself.. the service was great! All the staff were so helpful. The room was clean and as expected facilities were top notch!! The location is great especially if you're not so into staying right in the middle of all the hustle and bustle but want to still be close enough to experience it.We had drinks one night at the hotel bar - again service was great!!I would definitely recommend staying at this hotel!!
Reviews.Author: MissyVolt

Reviews.Content: A great place to get into the time zone! We were travelling with children aged 7 and 9 on route to New Zealand, so decided to make a stop, to break up the journey. we stayed here for 2 nights and it was the perfect place to catch up with the time zone! A large Western style hotel, with big beds and food our 7 year old didn't turn her nose up at! A swimming pool on the top floor (extra payment required), had great views. It is very close to the underground and located on the east of Tokyo. Very near nightlife - but far enough away for the noise to not be a problem. I would definitely stay here again!
Reviews.Author: RAECambridge_UK

Reviews.Content: Overall Stay @ The Hyatt Regency Tokyo...Ok I stayed one night at the Hyatt Tokyo Regency on February 3rd, 2008. Check in was relatively smooth and friendly. I was even upgraded from a standard King room to a View King. The rooms are indeed a bit dated and do need renovation. I would assume the Hyatt group/management do realize this already. The room feels like it's right out of the Eighties...although the complimentary Internet in the View King rooms are a nice touch (at last-free internet in the room). The lobby itself is quite a large space and the check in counters, concierge counter, cashier, and so forth do remind me of some Hyatt properties that go for a smooth but simple elegance. I would however say that the elevators seriously need some maintenance. I did want to try their rooftop pool at their Health Club called Joule but unfortunately had little time in Tokyo.I had dinner at omborato on the third floor. No special design or theme in the restaurant but the service and food was fairly average for 5,000 yen in a hotel.Overall, I can't fault the Hyatt too much - but I can't say that it was a great stay. I picked this property because I was expecting a modern Hyatt property. Another reason why I picked this property was because for 26,000 yen - it was a fairly affordable sum for one night. The Grand Hyatt and the Park Hyatt is at least double that amount. If you do go to the Hyatt Regency Tokyo, expect no heights in hotel grandeur, but it will be a decent enough stay to say the least.
Reviews.Author: Travel_Critic999

Reviews.Content: It's a good stay Very friendly staff and clean rooms. The sound proofing is great. The bathroom is a bit on the small side. Internet is complimentary and a ethernet cord is provided in the drawer.There's a convenient shuttle bus to shinjuku station or you can walk there. The airport limosine bus comes to the hotel and can be reservedat the bell desk.
Reviews.Author: lanceralot

Reviews.Content: Rooms are Dated My hubby and I stayed here for two nights recently and found the hotel to be just ok. The rooms are very dated (old furniture  tv) and the bathroom was very small. The rooms have this large gold key to open the door which was odd (rather than the swipe card key system). We were on a Hyatt Gold Passport level floor (23rd floor). The staff were helpful and polite.We also didn't like the location much, it seemed like the hotel was out on it's own in a rather deserted / business like area. Although Shinjuku was only about a 10 min walk away (and they have a free shuttle bus) - there just didn't seem to be any action as soon as you stepped out the hotel door, which is what we prefer. We arrived at the hotel by the metro and exited at Nishi-Shinjuku station - this was only about a 5 min walk to the hotel and was well signed.
Reviews.Author: buzziebee

Reviews.Content: Just OK, but not great. Three adults stayed here for 2 nights just last week. The hotel itself is in a great location with nightlife, restaurants and shopping very close by. If arriving on the subway, make sure you get actual directions to bus stop number 35 (the hotel shuttle bus), or else you will get lost. We did and its very confusing. This is my 2nd time to Japan, and for a Hyatt this one is lacking. The rooms are VERY dated, the air didn't work at all. When I complained, and the 'housekeeping' manager came to the room, I told him the room is 10 degrees hotter than the hallway, there is a puddle due to condensation on the window sill. He advised to turn the air con off and all will be OK. It was a tad better but not by much. I complained at check out, and although sincere with their apologies, stating they are working on the air conditioning, no rebate or consideration was given. On the plus side, the rooms for Japan are quite large, the pool is beautiful, the staff in the bar superlative. Beware - breakfast is very expensive. I stayed at the MO before here, and the food prices are even higher here! As a travel professional I will not be staying here again, neither can I recommend it to anyone else.Stephen
Reviews.Author: Slocker

Reviews.Content: Good location but fairly old style hotel I stayed in this hotel several nights before I found an apartment in Tokyo. Room size is large in Tokyo standard, but the hotel is fairly old looking in the European Renaissance style. I personally prefer modern looking and zen style's hotels. It is an average hotel with nothing special. There is a regular shuttle bus to the Shinjuku station (by walk it takes 8-15 min) and the hotel is also one of the stop for the Airport Limousine Bus. There is nothing particular nearly the hotel except convenient store... so even being in Shinjuku, it is not very noisy and hence not very lively. It is surrounded by mainly offices. As everywhere else in Japan, service is excellent.
Reviews.Author: Sophie_In_Taipei

Reviews.Content: Hyatt Regency Tokyo a.k.a. Century Hyatt Tokyo All I can say about this hotel, it is nice place to stay. Hyatt Regency Tokyo is the best hotel I've been to so far. They got a free shuttle to the take you to a nearest tube station so you don't need to walk / get a cab to the tube station.I love the view from my room which is facing the park. Excellent service!
Reviews.Author: shahril78

Reviews.Content: Excellent stay. We spent three nights at the Century Hyatt in August, having booked through the hotel website and having selected one of their club level rooms.We were very happy with the quality of the room, which offered all the amenities one would expect of a hotel of this type, and had a nice outlook over the Shinjuku park. Most importantly, with outside temperatures in the high 30s, the air conditioning was very efficient!The club lounge served a comprehensive breakfast buffet, snacks/soft drinks/tea/coffee during the day, and an evening spread of canapes, hot dishes, wines and spirits from 6-8pm. It is a very relaxing area, a great place to cool down after a day's sightseeing, with a very high standard of service.The hotel is located on the fringe of the vibrant Shinjuku area, a 10 minute walk from the JR railway station. There is a metro station immediately outside the hotel, and using this very efficient service any part of Tokyo becomes accessible.We would be very happy to stay at this hotel again when re-visiting Tokyo.
Reviews.Author: Travellers286

Reviews.Content: Renamed as Hyatt Regency Tokyo Hyatt Regency Tokyo has been known as Century Hyatt Tokyo. We stayed one night to dine at Michel Troisgros French restaurant.The dinner was superb! But our guest room, which has been renovated, was average.
Reviews.Author: Reed&Shiho

Reviews.Content: Great hotel in Tokyo This hotel is being renamed to Regency Hyatt Tokyo (starting Nov 2007). We've booked this hotel via Asiaroom.com (great prices)We stayed in it for a week at he end of August and loved every minute of it. When booking, we've requested possible upgrade to a king-bed-size room and got it without a problem. It also meant that the room was on a high floor with great views. Room size was very impressive even by american standards. Airconditioning can be regulated within the room, so not a moment of discomfort. Hotel has wonderful facilities (pool, sauna, spa). Make sure that you sign up for Hyatt Gold membership if you don't have one. It's free, but gives you access to variety of hotel faciliies for free (otherwise it's $20/day charge for the pool, etc.)All facilities are very clean.Breakfast Buffet was amazing in both variety and quality (it was included in our rate). They run shuttle from Shinjuku station, which is very convinient especially for tourists, when you just don't have any more energy left (otherwise it's 15 min walk). Also, there is a metro station right under the hotel (took us a couple days to realize), which solves transportaion problem altogether.Staff is extremely helpful. Consierge is willing to find our any possible info including printing Train schedules and explain how to get the tickets. If we ever back in Tokyo, we'll definintely stay there again.
Reviews.Author: olgab

Reviews.Content: Nice hotel, great location I recently stayed at the Century Hyatt, sharing a room with my 17 year old daughter. The room was a bit on the small side, and amenities nice but nothing special. However, the location right at Shinjuku Park, across the street from a subway station, and a short walk to the huge Shinjuku station, was great as a home base for touring. Of course I really wanted to stay at the ritzy nearby Park Hyatt, but given budget constraints I found the Century Hyatt to be a good compromise.I cashed in some Hyatt points to be upgraded to a Regency Club floor, and this was well worth the points. The Regency Club lounge had a fantastic free breakfast buffet - meat, eggs, fruit, cereal, capuccinos, fresh bread and pastries, all the lox you can eat, and a great view. Then in the evening there were free cocktails and hors d'oeuvres. Given how expensive food is in Tokyo, the Regency Club upgrade is a good deal.
Reviews.Author: divefan

Reviews.Content: OK BUT I stayed here previous through the same travel agent who booked this hotel for me. The first time I stayed at this hotel I was spoiled because I was in a Regency Suite. This past stay was in one of their not remodeled rooms which was ok but nothing comparable to my fist stay in a the Regency level room. Also I was a gold member but still wasn't offered the gold member room which I thought was odd. Over all friendly service at the hotel. I took the bus from the Narita airport to the hotel and the baggage handlers did a wonderful job of taking my luggage from the bus to my room. I would say this is a bonus for this hotel that the bus from the airport does stop at this hotel. Traveling with allot of luggage or a family this is the way to go whether staying at this hotel or not. Make sure you get a hotel that the bus from the airport stops at it makes travel smoother. The Odeo sub line is right across the street which makes it nice (one stop to get to Shinjuku). This hotel has got me hook just for the location. Next time I book I will make sure to get the Regency level it does make a difference for quality of stay.
Reviews.Author: mariobono

Reviews.Content: Excellent - will stay again Excellent hotel, services and experience.Room was very clean, well-appointed, comfortable and the hotel is very quiet. I loved the yukati robe. Turn down service left an oragami swan on the pillow. Ammenities good...can make own tea and there is a stocked mini-bar. Bathroom compact but clean and stocked with needed items. Staff extremely friendly, speak English well and are extremely professional.Location is great...short walk to the train station.
Reviews.Author: BDavisDecatur_GA

Reviews.Content: The confort and advantage of Hyatt at an affordable price Very nice hotel....in the heart of town. Rooms might be small, but anyway quite, clean and very confortable. Excellent spa and gym on the top floor and very nice chinese restaurant on the ground floor. Very conviniently located. I always go back when I'm in Tokyo for business
Reviews.Author: ghost7

Reviews.Content: Very good We stayed in a 2 x double beds room. The room was spacious by Japanese standards. My only complaint was the beds were more the size of a kingle single. My husband  I are relatively slim people  it was very cosy! The pillows were also rock hard. However, the room was very clean and the decor was fine. The staff were wonderful - they were very helpful. My husband is a Hyatt club member so a breakfast of pastries and coffee were free. The location is great - when you leave the front entrance if you go either left or right you will find many restaurants. The train station is a 2 block walk, with a lot of the walk being under cover.I would highly recommend this hotel just get a bigger bed. Also, the lobby is spectacular.
Reviews.Author: juleshPerth

Reviews.Content: Great Hotel in Shinjuku This is a beautiful hotel in the heart of Shinjuku. Nice large rooms with free internet and ours particularly with a Mount Fuji view in the clear mornings. Friendly and helpful staff are a main reason we will be returning to this Hyatt property.
Reviews.Author: mahalo11

Reviews.Content: Wonderful Service This was my first visit to Japan. My sister and I stayed at this hotel from March 24 to March 27, 2007. Our room was on the 18th floor and had a great view of Shinjuku Central Park. Room was immaculate and we experienced no extremes of temperature. I can't describe just how outstanding the staff was at this hotel...especially the concierge(s). They all went above and beyond with explanations, materials, suggestions, etc. When my sister purchased a phone card from an outside vendor that wasn't usable, the hotel purchased it from her so she wouldn't get stuck with it. We found the location to be very convenient to Shinjuku Station. I would definitely recommend the Century Hyatt with no hesitation.
Reviews.Author: AWOS1244

Reviews.Content: A good 4-star hotel We stayed here for a week in March. This is a very good 4-star hotel, and pretty good value for Tokyo. Don't be put off by how ugly it looks from outside. Inside, it's very early-80s in style with enormous chandeliers and marble floors, but it's been very well maintained, and the guest rooms are stylish enough. The guest rooms are a decent size, and very clean, but the bathrooms are a little old fashioned. We found the mattresses very comfortable. We stayed in one of the Regency Club rooms on the 6th floor. This gives you access to the lounge on the 9th floor, which serves tea/snacks all day long, cocktails in the evening and quite a good continental breakfast in the mornings. I tihnk it is actually worth paying a bit extra for the lounge - it's well staffed, unlike some other hotel lounges, and it's quite relaxing.The pool, on the top floor, is great. It's not very big, but then not many people seem to use it. Lovely views. The gym is small - a few treadmills and two cross-trainers, and then a couple of resistance machines and only 40kg of free weights. But it's fine for a hotel gym. Staff were very polite and generally helpful. The gym staff seemed a bit dozy, but on the whole, the service is very good. The hotel is very well located - it is only 5 minutes walk from Shinjuku station, despite what some others have said. All you need to do it take one of the West exits from Shinjuku station and it should be pretty obvious - there are signposts to the High Rise/Skyscraper district everywhere. It's also good because the hotel is one that the airport bus calls at. This is by far the most convenient way to get here from the airport - don't bother with the train. They both cost roughly the same, anyway (about Y3150), but the bus takes you door to door.
Reviews.Author: EuroLondon

Reviews.Content: Great concierge My husband and I stayed at Century Hyatt for a few days before we headed to Nikko to visit our friends. The room we checked into was rather small ( but is almost every hotel in Tokyo). We had a queen bed in the room. That left little space for moving our luggage around. Bathroom came with standard shower and tub. Breakfast was included in the room rate. There was free internet access in the breakfast room. I was most impressed with the concierge. I had asked for directions to a particular restaurant. The person at concierge pulled out the pictures of the surronding buildings. Then he pointed out the building we needed to go; followed by a picture of the courtyard where the restaurant was. No guess work. Excellent. Century Hyatt is within an easy 10-minute walk to Shinjuku station.This is a rather convenient part of town with lots of restaurants, post office and banks around the area.
Reviews.Author: singinggigi

Reviews.Content: Never Again We are staying in this hotel as I write this review. We are on night 4 of a 5 night stay. About me.... I am not a hard person to please or very picky but there are some facility problems this hotel can't overcome:Good:1. The staff is incredible. If I was rating this hotel on service it would receive 5 stars. 2. The rooms are fairly large (typical US hotel size)3. If you join the Hyatt Gold Passport club, you will get free access to the pool as well as a free semi-continental breakfast each morning.4. We are happy with the location.5. Some US TV channels. Bad:1. The rooms have no individual climate control. Our room is so hot that we can never look out the window because it is wet with condensation. When we asked about this we learned that the hotel has central climate control and right now that control is set on heat. This means if I set the thermometer in my room to 68 degree air conditioning, I get hot air. They suggested we turn it off and they brought us a fan.2. The beds are very hardIt looks like the good outweighs the bad, but what I value in a hotel room is simply a good night's sleep (couldn't care less about status or quality of the food, etc). With the very hot room and the very hard bed, we have not been comfortable in this hotel. This facility has a pretty facade but needs a lot of work underneath.
Reviews.Author: Kristiana

Reviews.Content: Very spacious, but average Spacious rooms and lobby area for Tokyo standards. However, service and decor is average. Location is no where close to the JR (subway) station, so quite inconvenient. They do have a shuttle service available, however, it's unrealiable and often late. They should be available every 20 minutes if it's on schedule. The food at their Lobby Lounge was disappointing. I would recommend this hotel if you'd like to fit 4-5 people in a room. Otherwise, location and convenience is crucial in Tokyo.
Reviews.Author: xksb

Reviews.Content: Need improvement ! This is my second time to stay at this hotel. I stayed 5 nights in Century Hyatt from 1 Jan. The reasons I booked this hotel were - No rooms available in Shinjuku during New Year - My husband is the Gold Passport Member - His company has an attractive corporate rate (17500 yen plus 13% per night)I contact their world-wide reservation hotline to book the room directly. They are so helpful and professional. The operator sent the message to the hotel to reconfirm the rate, especially on the 1st of Jan (most of the 5 star hotels would charge a ad-hot rate on 31 Dec and 1 Jan) and put us on the waiting list on 1 Jan. When I called them next day, everything was confirmed.Staffs of reception and concierge are excellent and I could not pick any mistakes from their services.  We stayed at the room of Gold Passport Level and had a pretty good view. Bathroom was refurbished, clean and neat. HOWEVER, we found some problems in the room :-Temperature of room is HOT AND DRY. I tried to adjust and temperature to 19 Degree (and of course it was not actural 19 Degree !), and put a large and wet bath towel on the cabinet every night when we're back , but it did not help! - Mattress was a nightmare ! We thought we were sleeping on a tight and hard steeling web - it killed our backs! It was not a proper mattress at all. We hesisted to request to change the room as we thought they were the same quality of beds. Hotel is not at the centre of Shinjuku, so if you're planning to have a crazy shopping especially during early Jan and early July (Semiannual Sale in Japan), you need to carry all your shopping bags, walk from the station to hotel for about 10 to 15 min at least, or take a shuttle bus at the front Odakyu Dept Store (Annex Building) (fortunately it has some space for the luggage but you need to queue up and wait it for every 20 min). The only concern of both ways back to hotel is about the weather - freezing in Winter and metting in Summer. For the Gold Passport Member of Hyatt Group, the hotel provides a breakfast room with pastry, coffee or tea. But it operates till 9.30 am, we only had a quick and light breakfast once of our stay.
Reviews.Author: cbym

Reviews.Content: Perfect place to stay       The bedroom part of the room, the sitting area and workdesk were in a seperate part
Reviews.Author: CamelClass

Reviews.Content: Lovely Hyatt I love hyatt hotel, it will never let you down.I stayed in this hotel a number of times, and I love it very much. It is located very closed to shinjuku JR station, very closed to subway station, and just beside this hotel, there is 2 tower that you can go up to its observatory floor to see shinjuku town.. and the best deal, it is FREE.
Reviews.Author: Travel_freak_mas

Reviews.Content: Awesome Hotel This is a great hotel. The service is perfect and everyone was able to speak English. The spa Joule was superb. I was amazed at the care that was given to me. It was the best spa experience I have ever had. It was the best way to loosen up and relax sore travel weary muscles. The location is great and just a little of the beaten path so as to be relatively quiet. The room was clean, big and had a great view. The only thing I can complain about is the bed. It was really hard. I would highly recommend this hotel.
Reviews.Author: Duncaroo

Reviews.Content: Comfy Room and Helpful Hotel Staff My family and I stayed for a total of 8 nites at the hotel. We chose this hotel for its proximity to shinjuku station and that it provides a baby cot for my 1 and a half year old son which most local business hotels do not. Let's start with the room. We signed up for the Hyatt Gold passport so we were allocated a room on a higher floor and it comes with free daily breakfast of tea/coffee with pastries. It's comfortable, very clean and relatively big by tokyo standard. Our son was able to make run around for his daily morning exercise. ;-) The bathroom is well stock w toiletries (like any 5-star hotels), clean and relatively spacious too. But the real reason why we gave it a five star is because of its service. We needed to get diapers for our son and the hotel staff went out of their way to locate it for us. Also, the concierge was helpful and able to provide us with very useful information, i.e the fastest route to a tourist attraction, opening hours, where to purchase the entrance tickets. Every morning, before we set off, we'll head to the concierge for all the information we needed to plan and get to our attractions of the day. This saved us precious time as we were able to reach our destinations without getting lost. It's no joke travelling with an active toddler so the last thing we want is to wander the streets of Tokyo trying to figure out the right direction.So, we'll definitely stay there again if we are travelling as a family.
Reviews.Author: anticipating

Reviews.Content: Outstanding Service This hotel is nicely located close to subways and busses. I stayed for 4 days and was able to sightsee everything I wanted to see in Tokyo on this trip. The consierge is extremely helpful. Every day will give me custom maps to guide me where to go, what subway to take, and made many suggestions based on my needs. I felt at home in this hotel. Prices are very reasonable compared to others downtown. The service is outstanding, the hotel is clean and up to date and is a Hyatt. I had a fantastic experience that everyone should know. When I left to the airport to return to the USA I left a substantial amount of cash in the room safe deposit box. Hotel staff found the money while cleaning the room and inmediateley gave it to management who contacted Continenetal Airlines at the airport to inform me. While checking in at Continental at Narita airport, I was informed of the hotel message and that the Hotel was sending the money to the airport and that I could pick it up in one hour. I got all my money. I need to let everyone know that the staff at this hotel is not only extremely honest but would go out of their way to please their customers. A big AAA+++ to this hotel.
Reviews.Author: Isetta

Reviews.Content: Just What You Need After a 13-Hour Flight We spent a long time trying to find something decent in Tokyo that we could afford and settled on the Century Hyatt, which seemed at least doable even with the service charge. The Friendly Airport Limosine Bus, which was DEFINITELY worth it after the long flight, took us directly from Narita to the Century Hyatt in 2 hours. When we arrived, we found the hotel to be striking (the lobby chandeliers are RIDICULOUS!), the staff friendly and able to speak the needed English (as did most people in Tokyo, it seems), and the rooms clean, comfy, and welcoming. We stayed here a week and then, after going to Kyoto for a week, stayed here the night prior to our flight out of Narita. The first time we sprung for the View room, but the second time we didn't. Both rooms had great views and were equally sizable. While the hotel has a shuttle to and from Shinjuku Station, we never took it; it only takes about 5 or so minutes on foot, so we saw no need. A word to the wise: It took us a few days to realize that there was a subway station significantly closer to us than Shinjuku. When returning to the hotel, transfer at Shinjuku for the Oedo Line, going one stop to Tocho-mae. Since the Japanese trains are like clockwork, it'll only add like 3 minutes to the trip (which you save by having to walk less than a minute to the hotel). All in all, we would highly recommend this hotel - It's great to have Shinjuku's yummy food and bars so convenient after a long day of sightseeing. Keep your eyes open for the gangs of dancing teens! They really are all over the place at night!
Reviews.Author: hyrax

Reviews.Content: Great Stay This was a very nice hotel  the staff was extremely pleasant  helpful. Good location  very quiet (we never heard a sound while in our room).. Beds are hard (pillows were good, though).
Reviews.Author: globetrotter2

Reviews.Content: Cheap, not just in price though.       Itty Bitty Ironing
Reviews.Author: Ben-Austin

Reviews.Content: This hotel is definitely one to consider in Tokyo I can say without a doubt that this hotel is simply amazing. This was not our first trip to Tokyo , and this hotel outweighed the previous ones. The neighborhood is very quiet at night as its located in the business district of Shinjuku. The service and staff was excellent. The fitness room was more than adequate and the pool was relaxing, but the hot tub was a bit small. Everyone was attentive and courteous. My boyfriend lost his JR pass, and we thought it was on the shuttle. We told the staff and they turned the bus inside out looking of it. The food was good as well, but like every hotel, expensive. There is a McDonald's in the basement of the building on the left in case you crave fast and cheaper food. The hotel is located right next to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government tower. Tower #1 has an amazing observatory deck. The hotel is a 5 minute shuttle ride from Shinjuku station. The bus runs every 20 minutes and starts at 8am and the last bus leaves the hotel at 9:40pm, while the last bus from Shinkjuku station is at 9:50pm. In case you miss the last bus, don't fear, the hotel is just a 5-8 minute walk to the station using the tunnel which is right next to the hotel. The tunnel will take you right into the station. Very convienent. In terms of rooms, they are large for tokyo standards and if you can, get a room with a view. We had the city/park view and it was a sight to behold. I would highly recommend it. The beds were a bit too firm in my opionion, other than that, everything ws perfect.
Reviews.Author: Delorian

Reviews.Content: Good location, reasonable prices We stayed here from 25 to 30 March for the first five nights of our holiday and found it to be well located, with a direct train from Narita and good train connections everywhere. It was as good a place as any to attempt to recover from 9 hours' jet lag and a good base for sightseeing. If you care about photography, Shinjuku is the place to be to buy the latest and best cameras and lenses.The service was great and the room spotless, plus we had a great view of the park - and the cherry blossom - from our room. The only drawbacks were thinnish walls combined with the very noisy the automatic toilets.
Reviews.Author: Moth

Reviews.Content: No NHK TV Channel We just returned for a week, we stayed from 14-17 April 2006. Nice and quiet room. During the Easter holiday, there is no one king bed size room for the first night. We have changed from a twin room to a king size one bed room for last 2 nights. Everything is fine, except the TV channel. It's really surprise that they don't have NHK TV channel, which is a famous local Japanese TV channel I love to see. We can walk to the JR Shinjuku station, Toei station underground. It is much more easy and quick, but it is quite difficult to find a right way. Overall, I loved this hotel.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Live up to the Hyatt's name       With Sunrise Tour having lunch overlooking the Hama Rikyu Goyen
Reviews.Author: SingleParent

Reviews.Content: Overrated The Century Hyatt is located in Shinjuku, an easy ten minute walk from Shinjuku station (although there is a shuttle bus from the station to the hotel.) The hotel is located above the entrance to Tochomae metro station so you needn't hoof it all the way to Shinjuku if you need to hop on a train. Unfortuantely, the hotel's convenient location didn't make up for a series of little things spoiling my stay: I am a Gold Passport member but didn't receive such a room; the TV in my room kept losing the signal and the picture only came back on after giving the side of the telly a gentle slap; the hot buffet breakfast was cold; I was unable to call Australia from my hotel room and with a phone card from the pay phones in the lobby, and I had to revert to making a reverse charge (collect) call. The room I stayed in was not a Gold Passport room, but was adequate if a bit small (par for the course in central Tokyo).The staff were quite pleasant and helpful, but I doubt I would stay there again. In fact, for my next trip to Tokyo, I am seriously thinking about staying at a Narita hotel and catching the train in to Tokyo.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: High Standards, not too expensive Although we originally wanted to stay at the Park Hyatt, after seeing the prices we opted for the second choice Century Hyatt and we are so glad we did. It was worth taking a club King Room for an extra 拢50 a night as the priviledges are superb. We had access to the private Regency club where we received breakfasy every morning, snacks and alcoholic beverages every evening and tea and coffee all day (all complementary). The service was first class, the rooms were spotless. Shinjuku is relatively quiet at night, if you want to stay somewhere more upbeat try Shibuya or Roppongi.We went to the Park Hyatt for a drink and a nosey and didnt think much of it. It is like a maze inside, everything is far too spread out, we were 拢10 per drink in the New York bar and even had to pay 拢10 each to listen to the live music. Nice view but not worth 拢40. Too over rated.We are glad we chose the Century Hyatt and will definately be returning there in the future.Go for the airport limosine as your transfer from the airport, cost 拢15 each and drops you at your hotel.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member

Reviews.Content: Century Hyatt-lovely choice for shinjuku Just stayed at the Hyatt Century in Feb. 2006, had a lovely room on the 19th floor overlooking Shinjuku Chuo park. Elegant, clean spotless hotel, room not huge but larger than most in this city. Robes in the room, slippers, comfy beds.Restaurant/bars seemed expensive, but lots of alternatives if you are not on expense account, Dennys and Starbucks across the street!There is a McDonalds adjacent on the basement level (by the subway entrance)Important note: this hotel is undergoing renovations-my room on the 19th floor was brand spankin new....might want to ask for room on renovated floor is this is an option...
Reviews.Author: mrchillybeans

Reviews.Content: Great stay!       Shinjuku park from room

Reviews.Content: Friendly Service, Great Rooms, Oh how I love the Hyatt       More Room!
